content:
I had this as a clash, and I also believe it's not impossible in 15 minutes.
Of course, the guideline is not whether it can be done in 15 minutes, but whether it can be done in 5.
I suppose I could do it using a stack, where I push whatever is after "SUM(" and pop after ")", in order to parse left to right. But I'd also have to add checking for commas, making sure there are no other characters at all, etc.
My conclusion is that it is too difficult for Clash of Code and, honestly, not a very interesting problem to work through. Some will say that it is similar to actual work tasks, but 1. I don't buy that, and 2. that's not why I do clashes.
This contribution hasn’t received enough positive votes from the community. The "SHORTEST" option has therefore been deactivated.
This is pretty much impossible to do in a compiled language like C in 15 minutes, because there is no eval. This has also been pointed out by Andriamanitra and XorZy. Why did this clash get accepted?

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Clear statement, easy for Python and good contribution to learn interactions between languages and excel

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: this game is clear. and should be done in 15min easely.
I don't think this is doable in 15 minutes in a compiled language. Simply parsing something like the last test case will take a long time to implement in a language like C.
I think you should add in the statement that in the output, each result must be printed on a different line, or give an example will 2 computations.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This contribution has short and clear statement, that is easy to understand even for foreigners. Also, because this looks like things we sometimes really do at the work or at home, that allows us to feel the problem, not only to think that we just need to solve it. Good luck with that.

I agree.
Python & co will almost always have an advantage over C/C++ in CoC that's just the way it is. That said, I think this clash is too dependent on eval, so much so that is probably impossible to solve, in time, without it.
If you really want to go with it, I would consider making the test cases easier because, in effect, the nested test cases add zero complexity if you are using eval, while making the problem unsolvable without it.
Also the statement needs more clarity. You need to define what mathematical operators are allowed, otherwise it is impossible to know what an "invalid character" is.
 Also the solution you have provided would accept test cases like =SUM(++5,--5) which could conceivably be considered invalid, if parsed manually. And, since validators are hidden, a player cannot know whether such a case is present or not.
should implies you didn't try to solve it?
